Furthermore, good sons! Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain the nature of emptiness.ğŸ”½What
are the ten?
First, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of power;
Second, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of fearlessness;ğŸ”½Third, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of the unique dharmas;
Fourth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of the aggregate of precepts;
Fifth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of samÄdhi;
Sixth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of prajÃ±Ä;ğŸ”½Seventh, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of the aggregate of liberation;
Eighth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of the aggregate of the wisdom and vision of liberation;
Ninth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of emptiness;
Tenth, they are able to know the nature of emptiness of the ultimate truth.

Although bodhisattvas practice emptiness, they do not do so in order to eliminate, and they do not grasp at emptiness, nor do they see the nature of emptiness, nor do they rely on the nature of emptiness, nor do they enter into the nature of non-existence.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas practice emptiness.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas attain signless practice.
What are the ten?ğŸ”½First, being far removed from external signs;
second, being far removed from internal signs;ğŸ”½third, being far removed from the signs of disputation;
fourth, being far removed from the signs of discrimination;
fifth, being far removed from the signs of attainment;ğŸ”½sixth, being far removed from the signs of activities;
seventh, being far removed from the signs of practice;
eighth, being far removed from the signs of objects;
ninth, being able to know the signs of the unobtainability of cognition;
tenth, being able to know the signs of the unobtainability of cognized things.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas attain signless practice.
At that time, Bodhisattva Covering Cessation said to the Buddha, World-Honored One!
These are the ten dharmas that bodhisattvas should study.
How should they study?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The sphere of activity of the buddhas is inconceivable, because it is far removed from the nature of the realm of thought.
Good man!

If sentient beings contemplate the realm of the dharmatÄ of the TathÄgata, their minds will become confused and they will never be able to see this shore or the other shore of dharmatÄ, but will only give rise to toil.
Why is this?
The realm of the TathÄgata is inconceivable, very profound and difficult to fathom, surpassing all realms of false conceptualization, surpassing all realms of those who have attained something.
For this reason, it is not contemplated or measured by those who falsely conceptualize.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I now wish to ask a few questions.
I only pray that the TathÄgata will mercifully grant my request and explain it for me!
The Buddha said:
Good man!
All buddhas allow questions to be asked.
According to your wishes, I will explain for you!
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡a-bhÄá¹£i then said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Self-praise is not the way of a true hero!
How is it that the TathÄgata surpasses all in the realm of his own praise?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
I will explain for you.
Good man!
The TathÄgata does not praise himself out of self-importance, arrogance, greed for offerings, seeking service, attendance, or fame, fearing that others may surpass him.
Good man!

The TathÄgata is without pretense or deceit, his words are not flattering or obsequious, except to benefit all beings, to bring them peace and happiness, and to enable them to realize the nature of dharmas, to give rise to pure faith in the TathÄgata, to rejoice and delight, and to become vessels of the Dharma.
And are able to expound and benefit sentient beings.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
All sentient beings may not be able to know the TathÄgata's merits and powers, but now the TathÄgata needs to praise himself?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The sentient beings in this land have little faith and inferior wisdom, and they are unable to know the TathÄgata's merits and powers. Therefore, the TathÄgata praises himself to make them know.
It is like a doctor who is well-versed in prescriptions and medicines and can cure various illnesses.
Where the doctor resides, there are many sick people, and there are no other doctors who can treat them.
At that time, the doctor thinks like this:
'These people are afflicted by illness and pain, and they do not know the good medicine, nor do they know that I can cure their illnesses.'
Then, in front of the sick people, the doctor praises himself, saying:
'I can recognize illnesses and am also good at prescribing medicine!'
At that time, the sick person, having already recognized him as a good doctor, deeply generates respect and faith, relies on him for treatment, and all his illnesses are cured.
Good man!
What do you think? Can that doctor also be said to praise himself?
Bodhisattva Cishi said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
Good man!
It is so, it is so!

The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, are unsurpassed, great physicians who well know the causes of sentient beings' afflictive illnesses and can give the Dharma medicine. However, sentient beings are unable to understand that the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, well remove their illnesses.
At that time, the buddhas then praise their own merits and powers.
Sentient beings, having heard this, deeply generate respect and faith, rely on the TathÄgata, and remove the illnesses of afflictions.
At that time, the TathÄgata, as the great physician king, bestows the great Dharma medicine, causing all illnesses of afflictions to be cured.
What are called the great Dharma medicines?
The great Dharma medicines are the contemplation of impurity, loving-kindness, dependent origination, and so forth.
Good sons!
For these reasons, the TathÄgata universally praises himself.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas are free from all dependent vows.
What are the ten?
First, not relying on giving to seek anything;
Second, not relying on keeping precepts to seek anything;ğŸ”½Third, not relying on patience to seek anything;
Fourth, not relying on vigor to seek anything;
Fifth, not relying on meditation to seek anything;
Sixth, not relying on wisdom to seek anything;
Seventh, not relying on the three realms to seek anything;
Eighth,
Not relying on enlightenment to seek anything;
Ninth, not relying on the right path to seek anything;
Tenth, they do not rely on nirvÄá¹‡a to seek anything.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas are far removed from all characteristics of reliance.
Good man!
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have no reliance, they are able to roam through all worlds.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas are able to be free from all dependent vows.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas accomplish ten kinds of dharmas and practice loving-kindness.
What are the ten?
First, loving-kindness without fixed location;
second, loving-kindness without discrimination;
third, loving-kindness that attains all dharmas;
fourth, loving-kindness that attains definitive contemplation of a single object;
fifth, loving-kindness that is unobstructed;
sixth, loving-kindness that always benefits;
seventh, loving-kindness that is impartial towards all sentient beings;
eighth, loving-kindness that is non-harming;
ninth, universal compassion;
tenth, supramundane compassion.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities are said to cultivate the essence of compassion.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten qualities practice compassion.
What are the ten?
First, seeing sentient beings who have no refuge, no protector, and are suffering, they give rise to pity and arouse the aspiration for enlightenment;
second, having aroused the aspiration for enlightenment, they vigorously strive and quickly enter the nature of dharmas;
third, having entered the nature of dharmas, they benefit sentient beings;
fourth, for stingy sentient beings, they cause them to give in charity;
fifth, for those who violate precepts, they cause them to uphold precepts;
sixth, for angry and harmful sentient beings, they cause them to practice patience;
seventh, for lazy sentient beings, they cause them to make energetic progress;
eighth, for the sake of distracted sentient beings, to cause them to cultivate meditative concentration;
ninth, for the sake of those with evil wisdom, to cause them to have wisdom;

tenth, although for the sake of sentient beings one endures various sufferings and hardships, one's resolve is to definitely rescue and liberate them, without feeling weary, and one will never turn back from great enlightenment.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities are said to cultivate the nature of compassion.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten qualities practice joy.
What are the ten?
First, I have escaped from the prison of all existences, the raging fire, and thus give rise to joy;
second, I am able to sever the bonds of birth and death that have continued for a long time, and thus give rise to joy;
third, I have already been able to cross the great ocean of birth and death, with its various kinds of false conceptualization, wrong attachments, and confusion, and thus give rise to joy;
Fourth, I can topple the banner of pride that has stood for a long time, and thus give rise to joy;
Fifth, I can use the wisdom of vajra to destroy the mountain of afflictions, not leaving even a speck of dust, and thus give rise to joy;
Sixth, now that I am at peace, I can also bring peace to others, and thus give rise to joy;

Seventh, I have awakened from the long night of sleep and can also cause others who have been bound by the ropes of craving and covered by the veil of delusion for a long time to awaken, and thus give rise to joy;
Eighth, I have been liberated from all evil destinies and can also bring liberation to others, and thus give rise to joy;

Ninth, for a long time in the vast wilderness of birth and death, exhausted, hungry and thirsty, wandering alone without companions, wandering endlessly, not recognizing the right path, not knowing the direction, being able to recognize the path and also being able to show the path, giving rise to such joy;
Tenth, I am now able to head towards the city of omniscience, giving rise to such joy.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten things are said to cultivate joy.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten things are able to practice equanimity.
What are the ten?
First, in the colors seen by the eyes, they attain the practice of equanimity;
Second, in the sounds heard by the ears, they attain the practice of equanimity;ğŸ”½Third, in the scents smelled by the nose, they attain the practice of equanimity;
Fourth, in the flavors tasted by the tongue, they attain the practice of equanimity;
Fifth, in the tactile objects felt by the body, they attain the practice of equanimity;
Sixth, within the dharmas known by the mind, one attains the practice of equanimity. When engaging in this practice, one does not harm, injure, or destroy forms and other objects.
Seventh, within the suffering of suffering, one attains the practice of equanimity.
Eighth, within the suffering of change, one attains the practice of equanimity.

Ninth, within the suffering of formations, one attains the practice of equanimity. When engaging in this practice, one does not harm, injure, or destroy the nature of the suffering of suffering, the suffering of change, or the suffering of formations.
Tenth, within beings whose tasks are already accomplished, one attains the practice of equanimity. One gives rise to a mind of joy, pure faith, and delight, and thinks like this:
Although those beings have already liberated themselves, I shall cause them to attain liberation and practice the mind of equanimity.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities are said to cultivate equanimity.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas attain mastery of spiritual powers.
What are the ten?
First, manifesting disappearance;
Second, manifesting rebirth;
Third, manifesting youthful play in the inner palace;
Fourth, manifesting renunciation;
Fifth, manifesting ascetic practice;
Sixth, manifesting going to the site of enlightenment;
Seventh, manifesting the subjugation of demons;
Eighth, manifesting the attainment of perfect enlightenment;
Ninth, manifesting the turning of the wheel of the true Dharma;
Tenth, manifesting great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
At that time, Bodhisattva Covering Cessation addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Good man!

The Bodhisattva is the most venerable and supreme among the Tuá¹£ita gods, surpassing all worldly desires and realms without attachment. For the sake of sentient beings, he manifests his disappearance.
When sentient beings see this, they abandon the notion of permanence and give rise to the notion of impermanence. Relying on that impermanence, they attain heedfulness.
Good man!

Those sentient beings who are not yet free from heedlessness, although they give rise to pure faith in the Bodhisattva, yet due to their indulgence in the desires and realms, they are unable to serve and make offerings to the Bodhisattva, and think like this:
The Bodhisattva will remain in the world for a long time. We can go to the Bodhisattva later to serve and make offerings, and it will not be too late!
In order to cause such sentient beings to give rise to a longing mind and abandon heedlessness, he merely manifests his disappearance.
And those sentient beings, having contemplated impermanence, will no longer be heedless, and will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who should be tamed while in their mother's womb, the Bodhisattva will then enter his mother's womb and manifest his virtues, spiritual powers, and rare events, expounding various subtle and wonderful teachings for them. Having heard this, sentient beings will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who should be tamed by seeing the Bodhisattva as a prince playing in the inner palace, the Bodhisattva, in order to enable those sentient beings to attain maturity, and also to protect those with inferior faculties and little faith, manifests as a prince playing in the palace.
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who should be matured by seeing the Bodhisattva renounce the householder's life, the Bodhisattva, in order to enable them to attain maturity, manifests renouncing the householder's life.
Good man!
If there are gods, dragons, yakshas, gandharvas who should be subdued through austerities, the Bodhisattva, in order to transform them and to subdue the non-Buddhist paths, manifests austerities.
Good man!
If there are sentient beings who for a long time aspire and make this vow:
If the Bodhisattva goes to the site of enlightenment, I will go there and diligently make offerings!

The Bodhisattva, for the sake of such sentient beings, manifests going to the site of enlightenment, in order to cause sentient beings to make offerings in accordance with [the Bodhisattva's example] and definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who are arrogant, conceited, and unrestrained, in order to cause them to abandon such afflictions and to subdue the demons, he is able to manifest sitting at the site of enlightenment.

If there are sentient beings who delight in tranquility, the Bodhisattva, in order to cause them to ultimately attain the most supreme, highest, and most distinguished Dharma, manifests sitting at the site of enlightenment, attaining perfect enlightenment.
Therefore, after the Bodhisattva has manifested perfect enlightenment, the trichiliocosm becomes completely tranquil, without any sounds.
Those sentient beings, having seen this, all say:
'May we, when we attain enlightenment in the future, also sit at the site of enlightenment like the Bodhisattva, attaining perfect enlightenment!'
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who take those false teachers as omniscient and accept their false teachings, unable to escape from this world or the next, attaining perfect enlightenment, the Bodhisattva, in order to subdue them and to ripen their wholesome roots,

Furthermore, there are sentient beings who are suitable vessels for the Dharma and suitable to be shown the path. Therefore, the Bodhisattva manifests the attainment of perfect supreme enlightenment, goes to the city of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«, and manifests the turning of the wheel of the Dharma of the three revolutions and twelve aspects.
Good man!
If there are sentient beings who are to be tamed by hearing about nirvana, the Bodhisattva will manifest the great nirvana and tame them.
Good man!
For this reason, the Bodhisattva manifests disappearance from the supreme palace in Tuá¹£ita Heaven, and even manifests the great nirvana.
Good man!
The Bodhisattva, by accomplishing these ten dharmas, attains mastery over spiritual powers.
Furthermore, good man!
The Bodhisattva, by accomplishing ten dharmas, is able to leave the eight inopportune states.
What are the ten?
First, abandoning unwholesome dharmas;
Second, never transgressing the precepts taught by the TathÄgata;
Third, being far removed from stinginess and greed;
Fourth, they have already made offerings to the buddhas, the TathÄgatas;
Fifth, they diligently cultivate meritorious deeds;
Sixth, their wisdom is perfect;
Seventh, they attain skillful means;
Eighth, their original vows are complete;
Ninth, they are disgusted with worldly dharmas;
Tenth, they diligently practice with vigor.
Good sons!
Because bodhisattvas have abandoned evil karma, they do not fall into the hells.
Those sentient beings who are born in the hells are oppressed by immeasurable suffering and give rise to a mind of hatred.
Bodhisattvas are not like this!
Because the nature of the ten wholesome courses of action is accomplished, they will never be born in the hells.
Good sons!
Because bodhisattvas do not violate the precepts of the TathÄgata, they do not fall into the animal realm.
Those born there experience extremely intense and immeasurable suffering.
Good sons!
Because bodhisattvas are not stingy or greedy, they are not born among the hungry ghosts.
Those born there experience extreme suffering from hunger and thirst.
Good man!
Because the bodhisattva has already served and made offerings to the buddhas and tathÄgatas, he is not born in a family with wrong views.
If born there, the conditions would not be complete, and he would not be able to unite with good and virtuous friends. Therefore, the bodhisattva is not born there.

Encountering good and virtuous friends, he cultivates wholesome dharmas, and thus is born in a family with right views, where the conditions are complete, and the superior wholesome roots grow and expand.
Good man!
The bodhisattva's faculties are never deficient.
If deficient, he would not be a vessel for the Buddha's teachings.

However, because the bodhisattva has accumulated meritorious karma, and has served and made offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, Saá¹ƒgha, and caityas, he obtains complete faculties and becomes a vessel for the Dharma.
Good man!
The bodhisattva is not born in border regions.
Why is it so?

The people in border regions are stubborn, foolish, and ignorant, like dumb sheep. Such people cannot understand good and evil words and meanings, are unfilial to their parents, and do not respect Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as.
Therefore, the Bodhisattva is always born in the central regions, with sharp faculties, wisdom, and clear understanding, and is a suitable vessel for the Buddha's teachings.
Good man!

The Bodhisattva is not born in a long-lived heaven. If born there, he would not encounter countless Buddhas appearing in the world, would not attain the fruits of the Way, and would be unable to benefit others.
Therefore, the Bodhisattva is born in the desire realm, encounters the appearance of Buddhas, serves and makes offerings to them, and matures sentient beings.
Why is this so?
Because he is able to attain skillful means.
Good man!
The Bodhisattva is not born in a world without a Buddha, where there is no Buddha, Dharma, or Saá¹ƒgha to make offerings to. He is always born in a buddha-land replete with the Three Jewels.
Why is it so?
Because the bodhisattvas are endowed with their original vows.
Good man!

The bodhisattvas, hearing of these inopportune situations, deeply give rise to revulsion. Having obtained such revulsion, they diligently cultivate and practice, attaining all wholesome dharmas and permanently severing all unwholesome dharmas.
Good man!
The bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas are free from the eight inopportune situations.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas attain the irreversible mind of enlightenment.
What are the ten?
First, being free from deceit and flattery;
Second, being straightforward and pure, free from doubt and confusion;
Third, being free from closed fists;
Fourth, being free from stinginess with the Dharma;
Fifth, not creating causes and conditions for the destruction of the Dharma;
Sixth, practicing as taught, never deceiving;
Seventh, embracing the Great Vehicle;
Eighth, always giving rise to respect for those in the Great Vehicle, because they have the same Dharma understanding;
Ninth, attaining the direction towards the Great Vehicle, and being able to understand and enter it;
Tenth, regarding Dharma teachers as good and wise advisors.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas will not regress from the mind of enlightenment.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten dharmas attain the knowledge of recollecting past abodes.
What are the ten?
First, serving the buddhas;
Second, embracing the true Dharma;
Third, maintaining pure precepts;
Fourth, being free from regret;
Fifth, attaining unobstructedness;
Sixth, having immeasurable joy;
Seventh, attaining much practice;
Eighth, attaining samÄdhi;
Ninth, attaining rebirth through transformation;
Tenth, attaining wisdom without foolishness.
Good sons!
Because bodhisattvas serve immeasurable buddhas, they attain respect for the true Dharma;
with regard to the true Dharma, they uphold, recite, and explain it extensively to others;
they diligently cultivate the true Dharma without regard for their bodies or lives, and thus attain precepts, namely the purity of bodily, verbal, and mental precepts;
because of the purity of precepts, they attain no remorse;
because of no remorse, they attain unobstructedness;ğŸ”½because of unobstructedness, they attain immeasurable joy;
because of immeasurable joy, they attain much practice;
because of much practice, they attain samÄdhi;
because of attaining samÄdhi, they are able to proceed to purity;
because of proceeding to purity, they always attain rebirth through transformation;
because of attaining rebirth through transformation, their consciousness is free from delusion;
because their consciousness is free from delusion, they attain the knowledge of recollecting past lives.
By this, they are able to recollect many lifetimes, one lifetime, two lifetimes, up to countless hundreds of thousands of lifetimes.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten dharmas attain the knowledge of recollecting past abodes.
Moreover, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas do not part from good and virtuous friends.
What are the ten?
First, seeing the Buddha, hearing the Buddha, and thinking of the Buddha;
Second, listening to the true Dharma;
Third, serving the Saá¹…gha;
Fourth, never leaving the Buddhas and bodhisattvas, inquiring about their well-being;
Fifth, always being close to the teachers who expound the Dharma with much learning;
Sixth, always being able to listen to the perfections;
Seventh, always hearing the factors of enlightenment;
Eighth, always hearing the three gates of liberation;
Ninth, always hearing the four kinds of pure conduct;
Tenth, always hearing about the nature of omniscience.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas are close to good and virtuous friends.
Moreover, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten kinds of dharmas are able to stay far away from bad friends.
What are the ten?
First, they stay far away from people who violate precepts;
second, they stay far away from people who destroy views;ğŸ”½third, they stay far away from people who destroy dignified conduct;
fourth, they stay far away from people who have wrong livelihoods;
fifth, they stay far away from people who are attached to worldly affairs;
sixth, they stay far away from lazy people;
seventh, they stay far away from people who are attached to birth and death;
eighth, they stay far away from people who go against right enlightenment;
ninth, they stay far away from people who are attached to family affairs;
tenth, they stay far away from all afflictions.
Good man!
Although bodhisattvas stay far away from such bad friends, they do not give rise to thoughts of harming or despising them.
Bodhisattvas should give rise to this thought:
'Because the Buddha has said:
If one associates with and becomes intimate with confused beings, one will be destroyed by them.
Therefore, I should stay far away from such confused places.'
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten qualities stay far away from bad friends.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten qualities attain the Dharma-nature body.
What are the ten?
First, attaining an impartial body;
Second, attaining a pure body;
Third, attaining an inexhaustible body;
Fourth, attaining an accumulated body;
Fifth, attaining the Dharma body;
Sixth, attaining a body that is profound and difficult to fathom, beyond measure;
Seventh, attaining an inconceivable body;
Eighth, attaining a tranquil body;
Ninth, attaining a body equal to space;
Tenth, one attains the body of wisdom.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish these ten kinds of dharmas attain the dharmatÄ body of the TathÄgata.
Bodhisattva Stopping Hindrances said:
World-Honored One!
In what stage do bodhisattvas attain the realization of the dharmatÄ body of the TathÄgata?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Bodhisattvas in the first ground attain the body of equality.
Why is it so?
Because they are forever free from all inequalities, and because they realize and enter the equal dharmatÄ of all bodhisattvas;
Bodhisattvas in the second ground attain the pure body, because their precepts are pure;
Bodhisattvas in the third ground attain the inexhaustible body, because they are forever free from all anger and harm;
Bodhisattvas in the fourth ground attain the well-accumulated body, because they accumulate the Buddha-dharmas;
Bodhisattvas in the fifth ground realize the Dharma body, because they are able to penetrate all dharmas;
Bodhisattvas on the sixth ground attain a body that is immeasurable, profound, and difficult to fathom, because they have accumulated immeasurable, profound, and difficult to fathom dharmas;
Bodhisattvas on the seventh ground attain an inconceivable body, because they have accumulated inconceivable buddha-dharmas and are able to accumulate skillful means;
Bodhisattvas on the eighth ground attain a tranquil body, because they are far removed from all conceptual proliferation and afflictions;
Bodhisattvas on the ninth ground attain a body equal to space, because their boundless body fills everywhere;
Bodhisattvas on the tenth ground realize and attain the body of wisdom, because they have accumulated all knowledge.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin said:
World-Honored One!
What are the differences between the Dharma body of the TathÄgata and the Dharma body of the bodhisattvas?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The natures of these two kinds of Dharma bodies are without difference, but their merits and powers have differences.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How can there be no distinction in nature yet distinctions?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The nature of the Buddha and the bodhisattvas is without distinction.
Why is this?
These two kinds of bodies have the same nature, but there is a difference in the power of merit and virtue.
Bodhisattva Nivaraá¹‡aviá¹£kambhin addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How should one understand the difference between the Buddha and the bodhisattvas in terms of the power of merit and virtue?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
I will now explain this meaning to you in detail using parables.
Good man!
It is like a maá¹‡i jewel that has been polished and one that has not. Although they are both jewels, the one that has been polished has complete radiance and is loved by people;
The one that has not been polished yet does not have complete radiance.
Good man!
Although the nature of the TathÄgata's jewel and the bodhisattva's jewel are the same, there are also differences.
Why is it so?
Because the TathÄgata's jewel treasure is already pure and free from all defilements.
The Dharma-nature jewel treasure in a bodhisattva's body is not yet able to illuminate all worlds.
Why is it so?
Because it is not yet complete and still has defilements, like a jewel that has not yet been polished.
Therefore, the TathÄgata's Dharma body and the bodhisattvas' Dharma bodies have such distinctions.
Good man!

Just as the waxing moon, from the first day to the fifteenth day, its radiance gradually fills out, although it is the same moon, the radiance is not the same, so although the bodhisattvas' Dharma body and the TathÄgata's Dharma body are of the same nature and characteristics, the power of their merits and virtues has such distinctions.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattvas who accomplish ten things attain a body as solid as vajra.
What are the ten?
First, greed, anger, and delusion cannot destroy it;
Second, anger, resentment, jealousy, arrogance, conceit, and inverted views cannot obstruct or destroy them;
Third, the eight worldly dharmas cannot obstruct or destroy them;
